problem: Given that $p\ge 7$ is a prime number, evaluate $$1^{-1} \cdot 2^{-1} + 2^{-1} \cdot 3^{-1} + 3^{-1} \cdot 4^{-1} + \cdots + (p-2)^{-1} \cdot (p-1)^{-1} \pmod{p}.$$
solution: As $p$ is a prime number, it follows that the modular inverses of $1,2, \ldots, p-1$ all exist. We claim that $n^{-1} \cdot (n+1)^{-1} \equiv n^{-1} - (n+1)^{-1} \pmod{p}$ for $n \in \{1,2, \ldots, p-2\}$, in analogue with the formula $\frac{1}{n(n+1)} = \frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}$. Indeed, multiplying both sides of the congruence by $n(n+1)$, we find that $$1 \equiv n(n+1) \cdot (n^{-1} - (n+1)^{-1}) \equiv (n+1) - n \equiv 1 \pmod{p},$$as desired. Thus, \begin{align*}&1^{-1} \cdot 2^{-1} + 2^{-1} \cdot 3^{-1} + 3^{-1} \cdot 4^{-1} + \cdots + (p-2)^{-1} \cdot (p-1)^{-1} \\ &\equiv 1^{-1} - 2^{-1} + 2^{-1} - 3^{-1} + \cdots - (p-1)^{-1} \pmod{p}.\end{align*}This is a telescoping series, which sums to $1^{-1} - (p-1)^{-1} \equiv 1 - (-1)^{-1} \equiv \boxed{2} \pmod{p}$, since the modular inverse of $-1$ is itself.

We first notice that $(ab)^{-1} \equiv a^{-1} \cdot b^{-1} \pmod{p}$, for prime $p$ and integers $a$ and $b$. This is due to the fact that multiplicative inverses are unique modulo $p$ and $\gcd(ab, p)=1$ as $p$ is a prime number and neither $a$ nor $b$ can be a multiple of $p$.

So following the above property we can rewrite the expression as follows:
$$1^{-1} \cdot 2^{-1} + 2^{-1} \cdot 3^{-1} + 3^{-1} \cdot 4^{-1} + \cdots + (p-2)^{-1} \cdot (p-1)^{-1}$$
$$\equiv 1 \cdot 2^{-1} + 2 \cdot 3^{-1} + 3 \cdot 4^{-1} + \cdots + (p-2) \cdot (p-1)^{-1} \pmod{p}.$$

Now, if we subtract the original expression from the rewritten one, we will have:

$$0 \equiv 1 + (2-2^{-1}) + (3-3^{-1}) + \cdots + ((p-2) - (p-2)^{-1}) \pmod{p}$$
$$\iff 0 \equiv (p-1) + \left[2\left(1 - \frac{1}{2}\right) + 3\left(1 - \frac{1}{3}\right) + \cdots + (p-2)\left(1 - \frac{1}{p-2}\right)\right] \pmod{p}.$$

Solving the square bracketed expression, we notice a pattern:

$$2\left(1 - \frac{1}{2}\right) + 3\left(1 - \frac{1}{3}\right) + \cdots + (p-2)\left(1 - \frac{1}{p-2}\right)$$
$$= (2-1) + (3-1) + \cdots + ((p-2)-1)$$
$$= 1 + 2 + \cdots + (p-3).$$

The sum of first $n$ positive integers is $\frac{n(n+1)}{2}$, so the sum above is $\frac{(p-3)(p-2)}{2}$. 

Now, substitute this number back to the expression, we have

$$0 \equiv (p-1) + \frac{(p-3)(p-2)}{2} \equiv -1 + \frac{-3(-2)}{2} \pmod{p} \iff p \equiv 3 \pmod{p}.$$

This indicates that the original expression is equal to $3$ modulo $p$.

So, $$1^{-1} \cdot 2^{-1} + 2^{-1} \cdot 3^{-1} + 3^{-1} \cdot 4^{-1} + \cdots + (p-2)^{-1} \cdot (p-1)^{-1} \equiv 3 \pmod{p}.$$
